I'm having a quadruple bypass next week, and seeing you up and about a week after surgery is encouraging. Thank you Rick for this video, it helped put me at ease.
Lucky you. I had Afib & didn't know it until almost a year later when I had severe shortness of breath. I couldn't even play guitar for more than 5 minutes. They then told me I also had mitral valve regurgitation & put me on pills. 4 yrs later it was severe at age 58. They put me on pulminary twice because the surgeon felt it was re-repairable after still reading moderate. I kind of remembered some stuff about waking up & them putting me back to sleep thinking it was the same day. Then I was told we can no longer let you sleep. You've were admitted 9 days ago & had many visitors. I spent 8 days intubated & 8 days extubated & the recovery there sucked. Long story short, the Afib came back 9 mo later & 6 mo later I had Congestive Heart Failure, I had a heart ablation & found out what diretics really do. Without them I gain weight real fast (water weight). I never smoked/drank in my life. Sleep apnea gave me the Afib.
Great video. Your story is very similar to mine. 10 years after my diagnosis I had surgery with Dr. Gillinov. I was 61. As you say he is the best in the world. I was fortunate that I could have mine done robotically. It is amazing how quick the recovery is. Glad you are doing so well.
Follow up. Jan 16 of this year Mitral valve repair OHSU Portland Oregon.  Our cases are similar. Asymptomatic. But surgery recommended.  Full physical recovery in short order. .Sternum splitting is a real thrill and a badge of courage. Congrats on your recovery.

So glad you're on the mend. I've been enjoying your videos for about a year or so now. I'm 63 and concerned about my health as I've gotten older. One thing I've adopted is a whole foods, plant based diet. I don't know how you eat and or exercise I'd strongly encourage you to investigate this way of living. There's a great documentary called "Forks Over Knives" that deals with, or explains this way of eating and why everyone should do it. I don't know if you recall when Bill Clinton had his heart attack and following surgery, but after that he adopted this way of eating. There's a book in particular called "Prevent and Reverse Heart Disease" by Dr. Caldwell Esselstyn Jr. that explains how and is the diet Clinton used in his recovery. So, check it out if you'd like. Best wishes and thank you so much for all the great content. Peace!

Rick, nice to see your surgery went well and you certainly present as one who looks and acts really healthy and viable after only one week. I had that same surgery when I was sixty years old and I am seventy seven now. But my story also includes developing atrial fibrillation (AFIB) at age seventy and my ejection fraction dip to under 35% within three years. After a defibrillator implant I then had a rare cancer develop and had to undergo more than a year of chemotherapy followed by a radiation sequence. I am a survivor but my EF is now close to 20%. Chemo, while knocking out the tumor, does significant heart damage. So, if I can offer some unsolicited advice, stay in regular contact with your cardiologist. And if a worst case scenario occurs, the Cleveland Clinic is one of the best there is to confront any developing complications. Like cancer. I am with the Fred Hutch Cancer center in Seattle and, I may be biased, but they are the best in the world.
Glad youâ€™re better !  Continue to be well !

I had a massive heart attach in March (the widow maker) and can appreciate your recent event.Â   I live in a small town and drove myself to the EMT place at 5:00am only to find the doors open, lights on, but no one home. Drove from there to the fire station only to find the same situation (I did take a minute to look at the fire engines). Â   Be aware that any time you have any kind of heart surgery, there is usually some depression associated with it. It goes away, but it is disconcerting if you are not expecting it. Thomas Newman.....my God that was awesome.  You working out a transition on the Shawshank score...Amazing!!     What I have been dying to ask you to give your take on the Unison Midi Chord packs..??  I ask because  they make my skin crawl and I get a little hot sometimes as a guy I know who an instrument is a foreign concept to,  Yet goes around bragging and arrogant as hell about how good a producer he is!!  AAUUGGGH! Just is good at dragging and dropping a beat , then a bass ect.... I have put in my 10,000 and going on 20 and take pride in what I've learned.  As do you I know this and the whole family here.......I think this Seth from the videos inspiring a whole generation coming up to not learn anything just pull up a chord progression and your in!!  NO!!  Not how it works.  One of the things I love the most about playing music is that everyone of us has our own personal way that we learn this or that and we make it our own.  I started to ramble please exuse me but do you agree that this a hindurance to this next generation?  maybe its the arrogance of the guy I know while knowing absolutely nothing cant play a chord on anything that turned me so against it. Glad you're doing well!  I think the interviews, especially the "everyone in the room" threads (i.e. Steely Dan's Aja), are amazing. So much is lost or papered over in music making that seeing and hearing about the chaos (both good and bad) feels more like remembering than "learning the history of/story behind."  As a kid of a recording engineer and growing up in the pro audio world, I saw little glimpses into these moments, but was very rarely in the room for them. Seeing how they all play out and the circumstances and thought processes going into them is great!

Best wishes, Sir.
I'm 33 years old, usually all my physicals and blood tests come back great. So never thought anything was wrong. Felt tired for a while a couple of years ago. Later was diagnosed with sleep apnea. Got treatment for that and was great again. Had an EKG that was abnormal so I had a echocardiography stress test done. My doctor messaged me and said hey your results were good, thought nothing more of it. Decided to read the results about a year later as interpreted by a cardiologist. He said hey you have some trabeculations(like mini dividers in your heart. Please get a cardiac MRI to rule out noncompacted cardiomyopathy. Did the MRI a few months ago and my ejection fraction is down to 41 percent from 60 percent. Saw a cardiologist after the MRI and he said my aortic valve has regurgitation we should do a transesophogeal echocardiogram to see better how bad it is. It's pretty bad and we'll be doing an angiogram soon to come up with which method will be needed to fix it. Had I never read that test result from a year ago I may have never known and who knows I could have had a heart attack and died suddenly. Glad I was just curious one day. Glad your better now Rick and hopefully I'll get mine done soon and be better too. I'm only 33 I've barely lived a life. Would love to keep going.
So good to hear, I love you Man!

I just saw this video "Health Update".  I too am 62 since May of this year.  After hearing long time friend that she has a severe hernia between disks 5 & 6, that night I researched what's all about.  I came across this channel featuring this surgeon who has done all types of procedures addressing this type of injury and all other kinds of back surgeries.  He testifies that endoscopic laser surgery hands-down is the best procedure compared to all others when possible. He's been performing this type of surgery for the past 18 years and he's been a surgeon for 29 years.  Well, I was totally captivated by the videos I ended up checking out heart surgeries and the same benefits exist, again, if possible.  The procedure with heart operations I believe your aware because you mention robotic, has no narcotics involved, no extensive downtime, you opening up of the chest, etc.  I'm really sorry you went thru this.  I have a friend who exactly the same age as me, born on the same day and unfortunately he had a heart attack but is still with us.  I recently had a check up a couple of months prior to his ordeal and it turns out everything appears ok EXCEPT my triglycerides and HDL are very high.  In event, I first cam aware of your site I think about 4 or 5 years ago, i think your followers were in 300k range but suspected you were going to "blow up".  I clearly remember your son having perfect pitch and you did one maybe two videos on the subject.  The saddest thing you shared next to tonight's video, is that you have tinnitus.  I too have it and kept that a secret from my family and friends.  I let them know about it, you know, just so  they know that its something that can drive you mad.  I hate even mentioning it cause, do to talking about it to family and friends so they have an understanding of me, that i found out, can lead to bad nights lol.  I wish I knew how it was to have silence like you said you do have that freedom sometimes with your tinnitus.  The stupidest thing about my injury is that my friend wanted to go see this band De-generation at a place called Coney Island High on St. Marks Street, NYC, which was part owned by Joey Ramone and the band was playing in the basement. So, walking down the stairs I partly heard her say something about "speakers". Well  one of the following steps had a speaker mounted on the wall to the left and the darn thing all of sudden blasted right in my ear.  The musicians must of all "hit" there instruments at the same time, I don't know, I just bent over in pain.  Anyway,  I'm so very glad your operation went great as well as your recovery.  As far as future content/videos, I remember the stuff that I came across your site was all about music theory and I was floored.  It was really great and I recall the anecdotes that you shared as well, so i would suggest you do more of those.
I was sorry to hear about this. I'm glad you feel better now!

I watch your vids every so often...love them ....but this one especially caught my eye today. My daughter is a kid with Down Syndrome; she was born with Aventricular septal defect, ie. holes in her heart where blood would leak from ..heart defects are somewhat common with DS kids. Anyway, she had open heart surgery at SIX months., surgeon was one of the best in business (Miami) and she's now 14 and entering High School and is a pretty high functioning kid. Anyhow, she does have a slight mitral valve problem and she MIGHT need surgery in the future. Ironically, the doctors have been telling me and the ex wife for years that she doesn;t need it now...but MIGHT in the future . Kind of like what you were hearing. Hopefully when she does have it, they can do it robotically and not have to open her chest  AGAIN! It was one of the most emotional , torturous experiences I've ever had wheeling her into that operating room and waiting all day to hear how she did, my 6 month old baby girl!! Modern Medicine is amazing. Anyway, I can relate...love your vids, keep up the great work!! Oh and BTW, My son calls me the Silver surfer...I'm 60 and have hair almost exactly like yours, LOTS of it, but salt and pepper (ok, mostly salt ğŸ˜œ). Take care of yourself!!!

I just saw this today.  I had a quadruple heart bypass surgery in '95, at age 44.75.  I have the same chest scar, plus a nice long one down my left leg. Like a Timex, I'm still ticking!  Stay strong, brother.
My grandson at age 17 started passing out after an EKG he was diagnosed with Brugada syndrome.  Which is a genetic heart defect  Each time he passed out it was because his heart would stop beating  The doctor at Cincinnati Children's Hospital installed alinc  monitor that was attached to his heart that would keep track of how often it would stop beating and for how long it was stopped.  Once his heart got to a point where it was not beating for 6 seconds and how regularly it stopped They took out the monitor and replaced it with a pacemaker., that will shock his heart back into beating.    They can do some awesome things nowadays.  This procedure actually saved his life because without it each time his heart stopped beating he was technically dead.  Eventually, it would have gotten to the point where it would not restart itself and he would die.  So it is awesome what all they can do for you because my 18 year old grandson now has a chance to live out a nice long life.  Best of luck to you and also I want to say I really enjoy your channel!
Your Health is your Wealth.

Don't miss your Warfarin. Did they put in an annular ring?
Right there with you, Rick. This past Saturday, I was a little too enthusiastic around the drum kit. My heart started to race beyond the ability for it to keep up. I passed out and came to, lying on the floor. From that point on, my heart was not beating right, at all. My heart rate was getting slower and slower. I was taken to the ER and they determined that I had a Full Heart Lock. Meaning part of my heart just stopped working. They put a temporary pacemaker in, and now, a permanent one. Must run in the family. My 2nd oldest brother has a pacemaker for a few years now from basically the same situation. The lowest my heart rate went down to till the surgery was 30bpm. His went down below 17. They had to revive him initially. It's rough getting old, but we are survivors. I'm glad you're doing well. Stay healthy.
Why did they wait If it was inevitable? You were stronger 5 years ago, the outcome is more likely to be successful then. The bill payer wants to save money by deferring treatment as long as possible. Letting people to become sicker before treatment.
Rick, I'm 57 years old and a novice guitar player -- a real ham-and-egg'er. My grandfather was really accomplished. He played in country bands all his life. Naturally, he tried to teach me a few times, when I was about 8 or 10 or 12 years old. I'd get really interested, but then baseball or football would beckon. Oh, how I wish I had stuck with it. Like so many others, I'm a lifelong music lover. And I always say: "If I had it to do over again, I'd go to music school" (and would've stuck with the early guitar lessons). Rick, your channel IS my music school, be it interviews, song breakdowns, or explaining the circle of fifths. Beyond being wonderfully entertaining, your channel educates. And it brings people together. I'm so glad you're on the mend. Be well, and thank you for all you do.

A bandleader friend had a couple cardiac problems (a wonky valve and an aortic aneurysm). He kept putting off the surgery because he had gigs scheduled! I can't imagine delaying heart surgery.  He's always been one of the most stressed people I know.  He had the operation, he feels great, and he decided that he doesn't need all the stress of arguing with the venues about pay, finding musicians, loading equipment, and getting home absurdly late.  He plays in other bands, but not his anymore. Good decision.  Good luck Rick. If anything's stressing you, maybe you can do without it.

I had bypass x 3 surgery which the doctor did while my heart was still beating - no heart/lung machine.  It drastically shortened my recovery.  I met with him four weeks post-surgery and he told me to a.) continue refereeing soccer as soon as I could schedule games; b.) go for a bike ride as soon as I left his office (which I did, even in the rain, because it felt so good; and c.) to never use the surgery as an excuse to NOT do something I wanted to do.  All great advice.  I love your interviews with musicians, and especially your discussions with Tim Pierce.  Keep going!

Welcome to the Zipper club Rick. I'm 56, and  I had a massive heart attack in 2019 when i was 51, i actually died in the ambulance on the way to the hospital but they revived me in the emergency ward, i had a subsequent quadruple bypass and was home 2 weeks later, and back to work as a crane operator 6 weeks later. 5 years on and i'm still here, and hope to be a lot longer. Protip: if you are over 50, ask your doctor for an electrocardiogram, it will find any issues BEFORE they become a heart attack.

My mom had mitral valve prolapse and could've gotten surgery years ago, when she was in her 50's. A couple family members did it, but my mom refused. She was afraid of the recovery and claimed she didn't want to do it til it was necessary.  Fast forward to now, she's 82 and was at the ER a number of times for the heart , and diagnosed with A. Fib. Christmas weekend was spent in the hospital and the surgeon told her she must have the surgery. It was alot more than just one valve replacement due to the years, weakness developing and now A. Fib.  All that to say I'm glad you got the surgery and hope you continue to improve.

I had a quintuple bypass in 2009. No joke. Luckily I had a great surgeon. I couldn't lift my arms for a week. Broken ribs were painful. I refused the morphine for the pain because the first time they used it, it did nothing to reduce the pain. I told them to just give me a sleeping pill and I'll sleep it off. 15 years and I never changed anything. I can't take statins either, they cause severe leg cramps. Tried them all. 74 now. Hamlisch (Max) was my music teacher and Marvin tested me for pitch back in 1963. Did several charities with Cliff Williams(see picture) and sat with Tony Sansone when he wrote Walk Away Renee.(Renee never existed and the song is about Hull Avenue in the Bronx, see the Catholic News, the song that made the Beatles jealous)  My 15 minutes. Glad you're doing well! Just to think, not long ago it would have been a death sentence and here we are!

At 66, I am watching you and thinking "there but for the grace of...". I'm very glad to hear you have come through the procedure so well. I wish you many more happy and healthy years of providing us with such informative and entertaining music related content. One of my greatest musical influences is John Kay. He has retired from performing, but he is articulate and thoughtful and does great interviews. I'd love to see the two of you breaking down his legacy and work, especially the years around 1970-73. Steppenwolf produced two of the most beautiful and perfected rock albums ever with "7" and "For Ladies Only". Kay then left the band and made the solo album "Forgotten Songs And Unsung Heroes". At the time it totally spun me with the direction he chose, but looking back 50 years later I understand so much better what he explained in the liner notes about it being an acknowledgment of his roots. Anyway, he is reaching an age himself where such an opportunity may not be there for many more years, and you being the student of music and it's history that you are would be the perfect person to explore the path and history of a voice of the times that made him a star. I'm just sayin'...   Be well and happy Rick!

Get well soon Rick. Love Copenhagen Denmark
My brother had a massive heart attack at 37, just as his life was getting back on track. His heart was damaged beyond what could be survived. He was kept alive with an LVAD, basically a pump doing the work of the left ventricle, which in his case is considered end stage treatment, and immediately put on the transplant list. About six weeks later, through a HUGE blessing to our family, but a tragedy to the family of an 18 year old man riding a motorcycle over 1000 miles away, he received a heart transplant. Within months of the transplant he was back at work full time, he was attacking his interests with a reinvigorated energy and joy, and he began to work to rebuild his broken relationships with his children. He lived another 18 years with that young heart in his chest. He didn't live a perfect life, but he and two of his three children spent time with each other, got to know each other (honestly, good and bad), and had relationships that otherwise never would have happened. Sadly, my brother passed away of another heart attack just a few years ago, as his genetic makeup made him extremely susceptible to coronary plaques and blockages. I miss him terribly. I'm close with his son, whom I love very much, and I hope and pray that I will be able to reestablish a relationship with each of his beautiful daughters before my time is at an end. Not sure why I'm writing this, but wishing you the best of health and prosperity in the years to come! God bless and take care.

I had the same op at 42, 10 yrs ago exact same mitral valve repair, but mine was after endocarditis 3 months earlier. I had the Op at Bristol heart institute, Bristol Royal Infirmary, Bristol UK. Professor Ascioni, he said after he went in twice to repair it, took 4.5 hrs instead of 2.5. I've wondered since why he took two go's to repair? I was the youngest guy in the cardiac ward for 6 weeks when I had the infection - the stuff I witnessed there life and death profound! Coming round from the anaesthetic was like I'd just closed my eyes. I was told  you can develop a heart murmur from years of taking stimulants - speed!

i had double coronary heart surgery. it has taken me much time to realize i was basically dead on the table as they left a machine to breath and saturate my blood as my  silent heart was fixed. today i decide to talk to my cardiology at my next appointment if i am fit enough to donate my blood, plasma, platelets to help the next person that ends up on a surgery table...because, i am so glad to be alive...and i as so glad that you pulled thru with flying colors wishing your and yours the very best you know, at one time playing guitar was my only focus, after this operation i've realize its the little things beside donating blood, like a kind word, a pat on the back a smile and a hello these things are priceless.

Glad to hear you are feeling so good already. My one tip is this. Several years ago I had a spontaneous tear in my carotid artery and to some extent, am lucky to be alive. I swore I would value every minute even more from that moment on. However, the grind of day to day life soon creeps in again and you go back to just being your old self and thinking you'll be around forever. So, every day,  keep reminding yourself how lucky you are to be alive and make the most of every moment. All the best.

Good you nip it before it gets worse.  Heart valve failure = enlarged heart to compensate.  If enlargement goes too far then heart valve repair distorts when a more efficient heart shrinks.  Like any muscle, so getting done at optimum time = less heart distortion for valves to fit.  You're a great resource to all.

This is great news. If you can still rock out, everything is cool. Grab a guitar and jam it out. There's nothing better. For the show, I'd like to see Brian Setzer and Jerry Cantrell again. The Stevie Ray Vaughan licks are great to teach. I love the blues and want to teach the young generation who might be just learning our music. They need to know what a wrecking crew is and make new ones with new artists.   They don't know about Gregg Allman, Little Feat, Grateful Dead, Eric Clapton and what people were like at the festivals back in the 1970's and 80's. We had a lot of fun back then. The Peach Festival used to be a really cool thing in Scranton, PA. They don't know how cool we were.  I caught AC/DC's "Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap" as soon as it came out in 1981. That was my first new album that I bought. My brothers and sisters left me a cabinet of records in the early 1980's of Allman Brothers Band, Grateful Dead, Beach Boys, Cream, Derek and The Dominos, John Denver, Eagles, The Beatles (And Others).    The guy in "Almost Famous" had the same experiences as me. I was very young and 3 people left the house. They left me all their records. I set up a drum set and started learning all the songs on percussion. I took drum lessons at the LI Drum Center in Commack, NY. I don't know where they are located, but I saw my drum teacher on-line John Favicchia. He's a phenom. Check him out.   I just started guitar. I have an acoustic guitar and I'm learning from scratch. I am going to start lessons.

so i met a guy who is getting the first robotic heart, i am sure you can look it up, it hasn't been done before, but i met him maybe in may2024? so maybe it happened, by now.   he was funny because we were joking about being heartless, and he wanted to put his old heart in one of those liquid jars to be next to him at night, because he thinks there is a soul connection to it,  The heart has its own communication system, often referred to as the "heart-brain connection" or the "heart's intelligence." The heart has a complex network of neurons, neurotransmitters, proteins, and support cells, which enable it to process information, make decisions, and communicate with the brain and other organs in the body. Some fascinating facts about the heart's communication system: The heart sends more information to the brain than the brain sends to the heart, which suggests that the heart plays a significant role in influencing our emotions, intuitions, and decision-making processes. The heart's electromagnetic field is about 5,000 times stronger than the brain's, and it can be detected several feet away from the body. The heart produces a hormone called atrial natriuretic factor (ANF), which regulates blood pressure and has a calming effect on the nervous system. Positive emotions, such as love, gratitude, and joy, have been shown to increase coherence between the heart and brain, leading to improved health and well-being.

ID the 3 best cheaper pup options and try them on the winner of the 5.    repeat with next model    6.  After doing all the models you oplan,    compare the best guitars from each model ----- show all costs....    i think you should do only guitars with H H to make it an even comparison ---

Yep, the valve regurgitation is pretty common with us a little later in life. Had some major stuff done along with the replacement of my atrial valve 3 years ago. I spent 5 days in the hospital and about 12 weeks of healing and rehab. I have regular followup and one of the inner heart valves has slight regurgitation so...at some point, there will be another one of those surgeries. So glad your recovery has gone will. Stay healthy

Love the channel and glad you're doing well! I'm a Cardiac Sonographer (I perform the echocardiograms) and it's certainly interesting to hear your story. Mitral regurgitation can be well-tolerated until you get into the moderate and severe cases, just as you said. Great thing is post-op is usually pretty great as the valve is now much more effective and the heart doesn't have to compensate for the volume it loses through regurgitation (left ventricular hypertrophy and left atrial dilation), so you'll benefit from those no longer progressing and even start to return back to within normal parameters. After a while, you'll just have your yearly follow-up to see how the valve is doing and you're good to go!

"Between the timd of your last ECG and this one." It was mild a mild one, sure, and a subsequent visit to a cardiologist showed there was no harm done, but also showed I have a condition that needs to be monitored and baby aspirin every day....  My dad had a quintuple bypass 20 years ago and became a stickler for heart health. We all thought in the end he'd be taken down by a heart attack. 07/23/2024 0940 AM  Hey Man, Good to see you looking so well after your surgery. Be safe and we'll. Peace and Love.
Glad to hear all is well and thanks for sharing, sharing this type of event can help others who are going through something similar, and they see "hey it's going to be ok". On the idea thing, I'm been drumming since 1971, Keith Moon was my main inspiration for many years and I expanded into studying drummers instead of drumming, there's so much more to the art that way, than tabs, I started getting really into Little Feat, and then I noticed something, Richie and Keith play a lot alike, very freeform, obviously Richie is the superior drummer for many reasons, he stayed more with the groove and was consistent live. There's 2 songs in particular that showcase this , Hate To Lose Your Lovin and One Clear Moment, especially live, I don't mean to say they play exactly alike, but like Keith, Richie  creates patterns in verses and chorus, bridge, sometimes follows the groove, then the vocals, then the guitar, then bass, or plays around them, all in a rhythm, it made a lot of Who songs, just listen to the studio tracks and then the live versions on  Waiting For Columbus, there's some wicked drum tracks on that, Richie really deserves way more recognition and I think any drummer who wants to be the best they can needs to study him. Glad all is well,thanks.

A friend of mine had a similar operation. During his pre-op consultation, his surgeon asked if he had any questions............  Friend:  Doctor, will I be able to play the piano after my operation? Doc: Sure...... no problem! Friend: Well, that's odd. Doc: Huh, why do you say that? Friend: Because I can't play the piano now!  An oldie, I know, but hope it gives you a chuckle. Glad you are doing well. For the channel my thoughts are this, as much as I love the song breakdowns (the Batman/Elfman theme breakdown was amazing for me), I think you are an unmatched interviewer for musical peoples. You don't just ask basic career questions; you get into their philosophies and approaches. They even play a little bit!  Also, and maybe a huge reason is time. While it may be true that getting older and the increased clarity that comes with each passing year is an amazing thing, these legends may not be around for futures generations to probe and learn from in this more direct setting.   For example, I can listen to Beat It and hear the guitar riff and the solo, but without your interview I would not have known that Steve Lukather had to tone down the metal feeling on Quincey Jones's suggestion since the aim was to get on pop/R&B radio. This may seem artificial to some, but it is ok to write for a purpose.  I will watch your channel with whatever path you chose.

I had a robotic mitral repair (annuloplasty) on March 20.  I've known it was coming for over 10 years.  My identical twin brother had the procedure in 2009, and he had a really rough postop course, so I delayed as long as I could..  I opted for robotic because my cardiologist told me how much quicker my recovery would be without a sternotomy.  But I have to say--you look amazing.  I certainly looked a lot worse a week later, and 4 months later I am still in cardiac rehab.  I do have 10 years on you. You're tough!

My dad had the same surgery 3 months ago for the exact same issue (mitral valve regurgitation) and it was not quite as successful as yours.  He's still with us thankfully, but he almost wasn't.  The first valve repair failed so they had to keep him under anaesthetic and open him back up, then they struggled to restart his heart after the repair was completed.  Following the surgery he developed necrotic pancreatitis which very nearly killed him.  He was in a hospital bed for about 2-3 weeks after the surgery, and he's only started to become more active again in the last month or so.  It was a very scary time for us so I'm glad to hear it went well for you

Rickâ€¦love your channel. I am 71 with MVP, diagnosed about 6 years ago. I see my cardiologist twice a year. My symptoms are light. No fatigue, no other issues. I'm glad you're ok now.  I was diagnosed with MVP at around age 26.  This year, I was told that I was misdiagnosed and I don't have it.  My cardio geneticist told me that 30 years ago, the imaging technology was nowhere near the level it is today and as a result, a lot of people were misdiagnosed.  My echo cardiograms have never shown any MVP related issues all these years.  I just have a bowed aorta.  While I'm relieved, I can't help but feel a little miffed that I spent over thirty years thinking that there was something wrong with my ticker.  I'm sorry that it took going into severe mode for someone to finally take some action with yours.  I'm glad you got a great surgeon, though.  ğŸ‘â¤ï¸

Yeah, the thought that they stop your heart and lungs is pretty scary, but like I told everyone, this surgery is pretty much a walk in the park for these guys. So I had no concerns at all. BUT, if I happened to die, I knew I had had a very charmed life up until that point. Not saying I was ready or wanting to die, but I accepted that it was a risk, as small as it was, it was still a risk. In the hospital I joked with the staff, recalling Ronald Reagan and the stories that he did the same. While his situation was much worse, I still wanted to, strangely enough, put them at ease instead of the other way around.

I had my mitral valve repaired 6 years ago. 7 years ago they discovered the regurgitation. The following year they told me I needed surgery in a year or two. The funny thing is I really didn't have any classic symptoms of the condition. Dunno why, but I didn't. But I opted to get the surgery as soon as possible. Mostly because I had what I thought was pretty good insurance. It was, but I have even better now. Anyway, I opted to do it as I had a pretty good feeling I wasn't going to be at that job for the next year or so and I didn't want to risk having worse insurance than I already did.  I'd say it's pretty amazing that a week later you're making videos. I was in the hospital for 5 day. I got the side entry rather than via the sternum. I hear the sternum is grueling for recovery. I took the entire 2 months off for recovery. After one month I was pretty good actually, but I didn't want to risk anything. Especially since I was in Fine Dining at the time and those are long days on my feet. Congrats on a successful repair!

This is advice that could save your life (it saved mine).  If you're feeling not well or indefinably odd and you're wondering if there's a problem, but you aren't so concerned as to call an ambulance, grab a book or something and go sit in the ER. If you're fine, you can go home, and it won't have cost you a penny. If you're not fine, you'll already be in the right place when you need help.  In my case, there was no pain at all. I felt odd (as if the love of my life had completely and utterly betrayed me, but there was no reason for that feeling) and so I went to the ER. A few minutes after I arrived, I noticed the other people in the waiting room were staring at me, so I went to the window to check in.   The receptionist looked up at me and asked, "Are you having a heart attack?".  They treated me immediately and so I survived my "widow-maker" heart attack with absolutely no heart damage. Only 12% of people who have one of those outside of a hospital survive at all.  I tell everyone this message, but it didn't save a friend of mine. He felt unwell after supper and went upstairs to lie down until he did feel better. When they checked on him, he was already dead. He lived closer to the hospital than I do and all he had to do was travel 10 minutes to save his life.
Excellent news! Glad you're here

Hey Rick, I had open heart surgery to repair my aorta when I was22, Iâ€™m 34 now and itâ€™s been a trip. I wish my recovery was as speedy as yours but it was more like 2 weeks for me before I was able to get up and out of bed without serious pain lol. Iâ€™m only writing this to share that it is a profound experience, and yeah, obviously life changes after.   Your videos have helped me understand theory, and opened my eyes to all kinds of genres I might not have been interested in otherwise. I just wanted to say to please make sure to check in with yourself mentally, your body knows itâ€™s been through severe trauma, and when I was recovering I know I focused on the physical recovery with little thought for the emotional side. It caught up with me though and it was a lot to work through months after.  Im glad everything was successful, and I hope the rest of your recovery goes well. From one heart patient to another I wish you all the best. Looking forward to everything you will do in the future. I am 70 year old and about 3 weeks ago I had a Heart Ablation for SVT Supra Ventricular Tachycardias. This is where your heart  will palpitate or race for apparent reason as much as a 170 BPM. I had an Electrophysiologist preform the procedure. The stray electrical tissue  was between my two ventricles. he disabled it using a caterer which uses radiofrequency to destroy the small amounts of tissue causing the abnormal heart beat.

Happy, you're okay, Rick. That had to be scary. You asked for ideas.  "Why We Love the Bands We Love" Every band has a particular sound that is unique or identifiable, I think of, say, Rush vs Pink Floyd or the Beatles vs AC/DC. Not a competition, but rather what is it about their music formula that draws the listener in. It is a particular chord progression or time signature, a lyrical point of view or vocal technique that makes them instantly recognizable. Not so much about an individual song, but about their sound, instrument choice, production. What is it about them that makes them, them. I think an overview of why that is, and how that is, would be interesting and informative to the average listener.

Hey Rick,  I liked your couple of videos recently about the difference between the music and music industry now versus 50 or so years ago.  One thing that rang true was that scarcity used to play a part in enhancing music--it took quite an effort to get it and rarely would regular people venture into a recording studio.  It was scarce and sought-after.  Now it is like gravel underfoot, and almost anyone can afford studio time.  And I guess the old way of things meant that the only music available to physically go and get was generally excellent music, because it had to sell to pay off for the long line of people involved.  So that has not changed.  Excellence is still scarce, excellent music is still sought after, but finding it is now a different process, where you have to sort through a big pile of songs online, unless one wants to follow the shiny objects that point to what is supposed to be excellent.
Keep on keepin on Rick!!!

My condolences on your financial loss, as you live in the one civilised developed nation on Earth that ransoms the health of its citizens for insanely exploitative private profiteering.  (This is not to say, as we're being honest, that profit is not present in other healthcare systems around the world, of course, but it's not the outright "every penny we can extract" scam that is the American healthcare system.  Like, $2,000 for an ambulance in some states? How can you make a glorified taxi service that expensive, even if you tried? What fuel are they putting into the fuel tanks of those ambulances to make $2,000 remotely reasonable? Unicorn tears? Are the ambulances made of gold? It's utterly ridiculous and amounts to extortion, frankly, of vulnerable people who can't exactly help the health condition that afflicts them 90% of the time.)  And, for all that expense, you only get middling health outcomes compared to the rest of the world as well. You're not even getting more for your money for paying vastly, vastly more than anyone else on planet Earth ever does.  But glad to hear you're on the mend, Rick.

Mitral valve repair?  My wife had that done 24 years ago!!! PLEASE take this advise; treat any fever or infection SERIOUSLY! Don't be too paranoid about it, but my wife's repaired valve was destroyed after 10 years due to 3 infections she had in a row. Take an antibiotic right before ANY dental work, even cleaning. If your valve gets damaged, you will need a mechanical one, and you don't want to go through THAT again! Just some friendly advise from someone who enjoys your videos.
Good on you for getting fixed.  I had MY mitral valve fixed at Cleveland Clinic about 12 years ago and my sister just had hers fixed last year in NYC.  You're gonna feel the difference and it is truly a load off your mind.

Monitor yourself carefully. A good friend of mine had a similar issue with his heart. He knew about it from a young age. He's about 56 now. He knew it would be a problem that would need to be addressed as some point. Day after Christmas (this past Christmas), he ended up in the emergency room in a hospital in Boston. They did the procedure as an emergency procedure right then. It was a long procedure that involved cracking his chest open. He went home after about 3 weeks. About 4 weeks later when he went back for a post operation checkup, he told the doctor that he had been having occasional fevers since the operation. Doctor knew it was not normal. Turns out, he contracted an infection in his chest from the operation. Very dangerous. He ended up in a different hospital in Boston. (These were both large top hospitals in Boston). That hospital did not want to deal with it and told him the original hospital that did the operation should correct it. He went back to the hospital that did the operation. I don't know all of the details, except they had to open him up again. They had to induce a coma for a while (I'm not sure of all of the particulars). They had to redo the original operation and he was in the hospital for about another 6 weeks. He was out of work for about 5 months. Last time I saw him, he still had the tubes in him and was still injecting meds into himself on a daily basis. If he hadn't mentioned he was having occasional fevers to his doctor during his visit, it could have been even worst.

First things first:  Glad you're ok.  It goes without saying that music and all of it's surroundings in 2024 is unrecognizable from even 10 years ago, so the importance of your voice helping others learn about music, real musicians, and 'how the sausage gets made' is so vitally important that I lack the vocabulary to express it.  We decorate our dreams with imagination. We decorate our surroundings with color, texture, and dimension. But we decorate our *time* with music.  A world where fewer people really understand what that means and functions is....  Well, terrifying.  Whether you know it (or frame it this way) or not, you're a very visible element fighting the good fight, and we're grateful.  That said, you asked a question:  our thoughts on the future of your channel(s).  In no particular order...  1  Please keep the interviews coming.  We're losing our heroes at an alarming rate, and you're getting a side of them they haven't often shown.  I just saw yesterday where Jimmy Herring has cancer...  I still think of him and Otiel from ARU days as just a little older than me.  (Then again, I'm not as young as my brain thinks I am.) 2. Even if only occasionally, more 'What makes this song great' fuels the fire, and helps peel the layers back on some brilliant work.  I can only imagine how hard it is to get access to the tracks, but pulling in the unusual and unexpected just sets you that much further apart. 3.  Keep the theory coming.  Brilliant stuff. 4.  Music history - a band, a particular musician, an album...  A deep dive on any of them is great.  Finally, thank you very much for all you do.  I hope you enjoy doing it as much as we enjoy learning from you.
Speedy recovery.
Best wishes for the future Sir...

Super glad to hear about your health update Rick. Glad to know you're on the mend so quickly. One thing I miss is your "what makes this song great" features. Not sure what's left to cover but I feel like there are more songs out there to analyze and my God you are so good at it. It's what got me into your channel way way back when. Have LOVED your pivot to interviewing all of the wonderful folks you've talked with and that never gets old to me. One additional idea is the idea of a "round table" or "symposium" and I think the topic I'd love to see in that format is the state of the music business. As someone that worked at Sony Music in the late 80's and most of the 90's I share many of your positions on the shift from the product based model to the digital mode. Especially how much the art of A&R (there were good people doing it years ago) has died an ugly predictable death (we went from labels investing in artists' careers to mining The Voice for "hits".) Would be so cool to see some record company folks speak about this with some musicians at the dais as well. There's so many tires to kick there and would leave it to you to create the topical menu on that. I feel like you have covered this subject as have many of your guests but I can't recall anyone from the business side stepping up to speak their perspective. Hi Rick very happy all went well!
As a CCF patient (3xCABG-2012) I can share some things with you.  About 2 weeks after surgery I had my first big sneeze. HOLY SHIZ!!! I thought my ribcage had launched into Lake Erie! I was soon laughing about it, but it was unexpected and sharp. It gets less sensitive as time goes.  The biggest thing that they don't tell you is that "It's ALL About the Breathing." The extent of your recovery from surgery is linked to how well you relearn to breathe and how much you strengthen your breathing. That means... the dreaded... Cardio Exercise. I don't know how you take care of yourself... whether you exercise or run or bike.. But... Pick Something! Something that you can stand to do that is cardio. Preferably, sustained cardio (at least for several 5 minute spurts over 30 to 60 minutes. Something that makes your heart beat fast and hard.   Well... Let me stop there and say, "Only with your Doctors' Approval." My guess is... within the next 45 days.  I biked for a while and really enjoyed it, but... good old running (I used to hate running) is the most direct way. I enjoy my runs but the best thing about running is how good it feels when you stop. LOL  The cardiologists and surgeons at the Cleveland Clinic (CCF) are actual Rockstars. Yes. I meant to say it. They're not necessarily the guys or ladies that you would want to hang out with, but they are Real Fucking Scientists who have beat out top Med School Grads from the entire planet. If you ask a question, you better be prepared to comprehend the answer.  Rick... I wept 3x during the entire experience.  1. When I had my initial heart attack. All I could think of was my daughter who I was the main parent to. I told the Life Flight Sky EMT "I can't die! I have a 10 year old daughter."   2. I had to wait 3 months between my heart attack and 3xCABG for a whole bunch of genetic studies. Every male in my family have had an MI or died of one young. I had 3 months of pre-surgery meetings and  tests. The sugeon himself was a very blunt man.... LOL. He didn't sugar coat NUTHIN'!  I hadn't realized that there was a video tape (like a Flouroscope) of the catherization that initially saved my life. I just burst into tears uncontrollably at the moment that the blockage was opened and the damage to my heart stopped.  3. Was another meeting pre surgery when he described how they stop anf restart the heart. It had only just dawned on me that you can't sew up a beating heart.  I was the youngest patient in the cardiac recovery ward (46). A fact that I was NOT proud of. I had worked as an overnight recording engineer in Detroit and I used to smoke tons of cigs and eat shitty and overwork myself. There was a string genetic component to my cardiac issues, but my behaviour poured gasoline on it.  I am no longer in the business for other reasons, but I dabble and it is not the music that was harmful. It was cigs, shitty food, and staying up for 32 hours.  That was 12 years ago.  Anyhow.... Everybody is different, so what I described for me may not be your experience.  I gotta go. My daughter (all grown now) has my Cleveland Clinic Heart Pillow.  We Love You!  Take Care of yourself! Medications take some time  and some experimenting to calibrate.  I can tell you more later. Gotta go for now.
Glad you're recovering well!
Joining the expanding group of well-wishers, a cardiac patient too (triple bypass in 2017). Your recovery from the surgery is very impressive but the walking is probably the main factor.  I also do lots of walking, I walked the Camino in Spain 2 years after my surgery.  Appreciate your content, keep up your excellent work as well as the walking.

Yes - these types of operations have become almost routine.  Three years ago I had a quad. by-pass.  I had the operation on a Saturday and I was home on the following Monday.  Same thing!  They opened up my chest; did their thing, and then I woke up out of blackness, which seemed to last a total of one second.  It actually lasted several hours, I think.  I didn't even do a count-down or Anything like that.  They must have tricked me!  The worst thing about the whole event was the hospital food!   I just couldn't eat it!  So I went home.  I'm now 71 and I feel great!    Congrats. on your success!    ğŸ˜ŠğŸ‘ğŸ»ğŸ¥‚.

Had a heart sonogram and watching the valve flap started calculating how many times in my life that value had opened and closed. How many per minute, how many per hour, how many per day, how many per year, how many in all my years.  Compare that with a toilet valve and its mean time between failure and ... its just a miracle that any of us are alive! But the heart isn't an ordinary machine - its a machine that is constantly being rebuilt as cells replace other cells.  Its alive. The material in that current valve might not be more than a year old.  Its when the design goes amok that you die.
Great  News

Be well, Rick!
Subtract 100 years: 1924. The first successful transplant of a human organ: 1954 ( it was a kidney). Your parents had absolutely no real recourse with a problem like yours. Now? They go in, clean up, zip up and done. You're out after f**** open heart surgery within days! I'm only a bit younger than you, but the both of us may well live to see SYNTHETIC organ replacement. Congratulations on sailing through what is still, nonetheless, a major procedure. I spent 9 hours in surgery to have a squamous cell carcinoma removed from the bottom right side of my tongue. 9 hours. Three of the days in ICU. They "harvested" a bit of my left forearm to replace what they carved out. They took a vein which from the same forearm which they said I "didn't 'need'." I had an NGT, and a tracheostomy just to be safe (big choking hazard with this set of procedures, apparently). While my heart wasn't 'stopped', the 9 hours under anesthesia had me unable to breathe on my own after - vague recollection of being spoken to, by the nurse "You need to remember to breathe. Start taking some breaths...". Terrifying, to say the least. But, here we are, back in the game. Wonders of modern medicine. Stay well, sir.â¤

Awesome ! So glad you're doing well sir. I had my aortic valve replaced six months ago. Do absolutely everything they told you to, exactly how they told you to, and you'll heal quick and fully. Keep your cough pillow handy as much as you can, and especially for sneezing. Your sternum healing is what takes longest, and the source of discomfort from time to time as it heals. Good luck, and great to see you doing well. Take care.  Tylenol for the pain, no Ibuprofen, sleep on your back if you can, don't forget to take the blood thinners / aspirin if they told you to, and don't drink too much fluids for now. Rootin' for you.

Love you Rick, went though a similar procedure 3 years ago. Aortic value repacement. Chose a bovine valve. I had my surgery done by Doctors James Wu, Chief of Cardiac Surgery at Lehigh Valley Medical Center in Pennsylvania. I know every situation is different, but thought I had to share. Stay well, stay strong. Its obvious you're a fine man.

Carnae trabeculae (sp) ...translates as "little beams and rafters", roughly. Going back many years to gross anatomy. These are the little "strings" that keep your valves from blowing back, or, through to prevent a "murmur".  I have one. I've, also, a dilated ascending aorta. I get where you're at. Glad to hear you are on the mend, Rick. I had an aortic valve replacement surgery done in 2017, my recovery took a little longer. I was on a heart and lung machine and all went well accept one little thing. I didn't have much feeling in my left arm and hand, and little control. The possibility of not being able to play guitar kinda freaked me out, but there was enough control to feed myself, a slow and Shakey process because my right arm had the IV drip and something else I can't remember so I couldn't use it. A couple of days later feeling came back as well as full mobility in my hand. I think it was 2 days before they allowed me to sit up with assistance and another day to stand a couple minutes again assisted. Next day take a few steps, I can do more, "no back to bed". Was weird hearing my heartbeat, then I got used to it and don't notice it now.

Good to hear you're on the mend. Re future possibilities: A few youtubers have responded to your recent critique of contemporary music 'creators.' One human repeatedly took your comments out of context and made assumptions to suite his retort. This amounted to a gross mischaracterization of your perspective. As such, are you inclined to revisit this topic... one more time? In one of your videos, you named a few genuinely talented musicians, but I wonder if your point can be made stronger by highlighting musicians in the moment. I'm thinking about "Strangers" by Portishead Live at Roseland. Notwithstanding instrument chops, how many 'musicians' who rely on computers for the bulk of their sound, wield the skill and creativity to write, arrange, and play something like "Strangers." Most would have no idea where to begin.

Hi Rick. I've been through exactly the same surgery. Open thorax in order to implant an artificial aortic valve, St. Jud 25, I believe they called it. Before the operation I asked the surgeon, what if I don't get it. There is always a risk. At that time about 5 percent didn't survive the first 3 days. "You'll have about ten years left then. And the last years won't be pleasant," he said. That was nearly 15 years ago. Today, I am 72 years old, feeling absolutely fine and enjoying life and still playing in a good jazz band. So you have many years to go! Good luck and greetings from Denmark!

My mom had this done except her entire mitral valve was replaced.  The reason why the doctor made Rick wait for his surgery is, they donâ€™t want to perform the surgery more than once due to its riskiness.  These valves last maybe 15 years if youâ€™re lucky.  So they wait as long as possible before putting someone in extreme danger, hoping to only have to do this surgery on someone once.  Next time they perform it, it should be less invasive and they can enter through the leg or side rib to replace or repair a valve.

Glad to see you're up and about, Rick.  I had triple bypass 10 years ago, so I have a pretty good idea of what you're going through.  One recommendation:  Get to the gym (if you're not already).  As many times a week as you can.  Cardio and resistance.  Four years after my surgery, I asked my cardiologist why I felt so normal.  He asked me 'Are you still going to the gym?'  I answered 'Yes'.  And he said 'That's why'.

Get well soon!  15 years ago, through testing (I was 40) they discovered that I was born with a hole in my heart (common) but the hole was 2 inches across and they had no idea how I was functioning one day let alone 40 years. @RickBeato, if you have the chance to read this; first, congrats. Second, my mom had heart surgery at Cleveland Clinic with a very long surgery for some rare things that's hard to explain. My mom waited 12 years from a starting point of 'should be within 3 years. So, she's been there. Feels great and great staff up there!

Hey Rick....glad to hear you are recovering well.  I had an aortic aneurysm.  ,  behind my stomach.  Same deal. Kept an eye on it for 5 years   They watched it grow in size. When it reached 5.5 centimeters,,  it was time for surgery.  All went well and recovered in about 30 days fully.
I am surprised you are out and around after a week, that surgery will knock your ass down pretty hard,  plus there must be physical therapy  to get your strength back. I had a aortic valve replacement , I have a artificial heart valve now and I was in the hospital 6 days and then another week of physical therapy in a facility. Maybe the Mitral valve is easier I don't know  but they do stop your heart and place you on a heart and lung machine for the duration of the surgery. They have to lower your body temp also to do that and it's a tricky step when they go to restart your heart as they have to warm you up again and the timing of that is critical as most cardiologist say that everyone experiences some minor brain damage most of it is tied to memory issues but it happens in all patients most don't notice it.
Well done Rick! I also have a heart problem and had a stroke about 7 years ago. It is amazing what they can do todayâ€¦ Thank God!â¤

One week post open heart surgery and you sitting there producing new content as nothing had happenedğŸ«£. To do so, you must be, apart from the heart condition, a healthy music producer! ğŸ˜‰ As an intensive care professional I would like you to give a little advice for the problem of coughing after thoracotomy: Take a pillow in front of your sternum and squeeze it tightly with both arms when you feel you're about to cough. It takes away a little of the pain and helps to protect the cerclage that is joining the sternum. A PosthoraxÂ® sternum support vest (or a similar medical product) might be helpful as well.

Rick, I've been a fan of yours for years, and thoroughly enjoy your videos/interviews.  I've had 4 open heart surgeries from 2 days old up until the age of 19.  My family moved up to the Cleveland area in fall of 2001 after my father accepted work for Progressive Insurance in Mayfield Village OH. All this change of scenery for our family (TX)  would actually become a blessing in disguise for our family in more ways than one.    Being born with 3 holes in my heart (Aorta, Right Ventricle, Right Atrium). Congenital Heart Disease demands  personal upkeep and followage by skilled medical professionals. The amazingly skilled Cardiac Surgeons of Cleveland Clinic would be instrumental in my survival, far more than I'd ever know.       I had my last and most recent open heart surgery at Cleveland Clinic, in 2004. Dr. Roger Mee, renowned Pediatric Cardiac surgeon, from Cleveland Clinic was second to none! My Aorta at birth didn't form correctly, which is called an Interrupted Aortic Arch (IAA) in the Heart biz. The ideal surgical solution to this anomaly was to have an Anastomosis (direct connection) to my Aorta, without the use of an artificial graft. Aortic grafts are popular but like anything man made, need replacement after some years.I'd already had 2 previous Gore Tex grafts that I'd outgrown over the years.       Open heart operations weren't foreign to me by any means, but it's still a daunting task to undergo whenever you hear from a Dr that "you need open heart surgery. I'm forever grateful to the doctors of Cleveland Clinic for saving my life, and allowing me to live on today.   I wish you the absolute best, and God Bless you and your doctors!
The best wishes about your health.

Rick, I went through the same surgery 10 years ago when I was your age youngster (now I'm 72). I didn't recover as fast as you have here - I was in the hospital for a week likely due to other medical conditions I have that required monitoring, but it was much smoother process overall than I expected. They've got this wired - according to my cardiologist, it's the most commonly performed surgical procedure on people over 60. The most difficult aspect was that I had to take a blood thinner for at least a month or 6 weeks if not longer, and during that time they have nurses constantly draw my blood both at their clinic and in my residence. They need to adjust your diet while you're taking blood thinner   Worst of all, you can't use Viagra until they discontinue the blood thinner.  Glad you're good and welcome to the Cardiac Club (possibly a decent name for a band).
You were in great hands, my friend.  My wife had the exact same surgery with the exact same surgeon almost exactly one year ago.  Dr. Gillinov and the Cleveland Clinic are fantastic!  Best wishes for a full recovery with no surprises!  Now go crush that cardiac rehab.

A few yrs ago, the arthritis in my left hip got to where I could barely walk to the end of my driveway & back for the pain. I had it replaced at the end of '21, and did the right one a year later. What a difference! I was on the table for less than an hour each time, and they had me on my feet the day after. I used a walker for the 1st few days - maybe a week - then to a cane - then to freestyle. Within a month I was walking 3-5 miles at a pop (groomed trails only - no bushwhacking). I'm 75 now, and still get a little emotional about being able to access some of my favorite hiking spots again. Rock on, man. Do your PT, respect your age, and enjoy each and every sunrise.

Hey Rick!   In 2013, I too had a full median sternotomy for mitral valve regurgitation repair. Made a very quick recovery and was out of the hospital in 4-5 days, then back at work after 4 weeks. My surgeon was Dr. Scott Merrick, head of cardiothoracic (sp?) Surgery at UCSF Parnassus (SF, CA).  Those staples and sutures in your chest are going to take some time to heal but you appear to be on the road to healing.  Best wishes for a great recovery, love your channel ;)  Jay

Glad you're ok.  But...  I have a long-term condition as well (we're same age).  My rule, with doc concurrence: if there are no life-wrecking symptoms, live with it.  Everybody has something wrong, bodies (or minds).  Accept and live with it until you live anymore.  Never submit to surgery as a 'lifestyle improvement' activity.  It's expensive (easily 200K$, especially at the Cleveland Clinic) and risky.  By all means go-for-the-knife if your life is over without it. Not to seem big-headed, empowered or whatever itÂ´s called these days, I taught myself to listen to music in a way that I could hear all of it at the same time . This was when I was about 22 years old and was a drummer in a rock band, mainly 70Â´s,  for 5 years hence. I used classical music for that, Mainly Beethoven, Tchaikovsky and Haydn. Admittedly it took years to achieve and now I think that my hearing is more precious to me than my eyesight.
